oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Letter from Bradford Dallas to Elise Croft about sending funds to the Crofts
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: A letter from Bradford Dallas, manager of the General Concrete Construction Company of Cuba, informing Elise of the new banking regulations that make it difficult to send funds from Cuba to the United States. He also details new agricultural reforms, labor contracts and settling demands from workers for better pay and working conditions. He notes that the financial outlook for the year is "very poor" and other companies are having similar problems.

Bradford B. Dallas (b. 1924) is the son of Charles Frederick Dallas, who was owner of the Antillean Construction Company based in Havana. Bradford managed his father's company and William Croft's General Concrete Construction Company of Cuba until he was forced to leave the country in 1961.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Dallas, Bradford B.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Cuba--Politics and government; Agricultural laborers; Labor contract; Wages
Laborers; Business & finance
